name.en-us: ACT Holistic Framework - Language Arts and Literacy V2.1

competencyText.en-us: Language Arts and Literacy
Developing knowledge, skills and practices to make effective language choices when comprehending, composing, and interacting with others
Word, Phrase, & Sentence Level
Vocabulary
Integrate familiar, literary, general academic, and discipline-specific words and phrases into reading, writing, speaking, and listening.
Determine the meaning of unknown words and phrases by using context clues.
Determine the meaning of unknown words by using knowledge of word parts (e.g., prefixes, and suffixes).
Make conceptual connections between unfamiliar and known words and phrases.
Use words and phrases precisely, considering both connotative and denotative meaning.
Determine how word and phrase choice affects meaning and impact.
Use and interpret figurative language and literary devices.
Grammar & Usage
Nouns & Pronouns
Use frequently occurring nouns.
Form and use regular and irregular plural nouns.
Use collective nouns (e.g., flock, herd).
Use noncount counts (e.g., sand, water, milk).
Use concrete and abstract nouns.
Use appositives to rename nouns in sentences.
Use personal pronouns.
Use possessive pronouns.
Use indefinite pronouns.
Use reflexive pronouns.
Use relative pronouns.
Use intensive pronouns.
Use appropriate pronoun case (subjective, objective, possessive).
Recognize and correct errors in pronoun-antecedent agreement.
Recognize and correct shifts in pronoun person and number.
Recognize and correct vague or ambiguous pronouns (i.e., ones with unclear antecedents).
Understand and explain the function of nouns.
Understand and explain the function of pronouns.
Verbs
Form and use simple verb tenses (past, present, and future).
Form and use perfect verb tenses (past, present, and future).
Form and use continuous verb tenses (pest, present, and future).
Form and use irregular verbs.
Form and use regular and irregular simple and compound verb tenses (past, present, and future).
Form and use progressive verb tenses.
Use modal auxiliary verbs (e.g., should, may, must)
Form and use verbs in active and passive voice.
Form and use different verb moods (indicative, interrogative, conditional, imperative).
Recognize and correct errors in subject-verb agreement.
Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb tense.
Recognize and correct inappropriate shifts in verb voice and mood.
Understand and explain the function of verbs.
Understand and explain the difference between transitive and intransitive verbs.
Understand and explain the function of verbals (gerunds, infinitives, participles).
Adjectives & Adverbs
Use frequently occurring adjectives.
Use frequently occurring adverbs.
Form and use comparative and superlative adjectives and adverbs.
Order adjectives or adverbs that modify the same noun or verb, following conventional patterns.
Form and use compound adjectives.
Use relative adverbs (where, when, why) to join sentences or clauses.
Use adverbs to modify adjectives and other adverbs.
Understand and explain the function of adjectives and adverbs.
Conjunctions
Use frequently occurring conjunctions.
Use coordinating and subordinating conjunctions appropriately depending on context.
Use correlative conjunctions.
Understand and explain the function of conjunctions.
Determiners
Use determiners (definite and indefinite articles, demonstratives).
Understand and explain the function of determiners.
Prepositions
Use frequently occurring prepositions.
Form and use prepositional phrases.
Understand and explain the function of prepositions.
Other Usage Conventions
Recognize and correct errors involving frequently confused words (e.g., affect/effect, capital/capitol, read/read).
Recognize and correct errors confusing plurals, contractions, and/or possessives.
Recognize and correct errors involving use of incorrect parts of speech (e.g., using an adjective instead of an adverb).
Recognize variations from standard English.
Recognize variations in the formality of language.
Mechanics: Punctuation
Commas
Use a comma before a coordinating conjunction linking independent clauses in a compound sentence.
Use a comma to separate an introductory element from the rest of a sentence.
Use a comma to set off the words "yes" and "no."
Use a comma to set off a tag question from the rest of the sentence.
Use a comma to indicate a direct address.
Use a comma to separate coordinate adjectives.
Use commas in dates.
Use commas in greetings and closings of letters.
Semicolons & Colons
Use a semicolon to link two or more closely related independent clauses in a compound sentence.
Use a colon to introduce a list or quotation.
Use a colon between independent clauses when the second, explains, illustrates, or elaborates the first.
Apostrophes
Use an apostrophe to form contractions.
Use an apostrophe to form possessives.
Ellipses, Hyphens, & Dashes
Use an ellipsis to indicate an omission.
Observe hyphenation conventions.
Observe conventions for en-dash and em-dash.
Other Punctuation Conventions
Use end punctuation (periods, exclamation marks, question marks) for sentences.
Use punctuation (commas, semicolons, ellipses, dashes) to indicate a pause or break within a sentence.
Use punctuation (commas, semicolons) to separate items in a series.
Use punctuation (commas, parentheses, dashes) to set off nonrestrictive/parenthetical elements.
Use punctuation (commas, quotation marks, colons) in dialogue.
Use commas and quotations to mark direct speech and quotations from a text.
Use correct punctuation in addresses.
Use underlining, quotation marks, or italics to indicate titles of works.
Use punctuation for effect.
Mechanics: Capitalization
Proper Nouns
Capitalize names and titles of people when appropriate.
Capitalize cities, countries, nationalities, languages and names or titles of entities such as organizations and brands.
Capitalize dates, days, months, and holidays.
Capitalize regions and geographic features (e.g., "the Midwest" and "the Atlantic Ocean").
Other Capitalization Conventions
Capitalize the first word in a sentence.
Capitalize the pronoun “I.”
Capitalize appropriate words in headings and titles of books, plays, movies, and other texts.
Recognize and correct errors in capitalization.
Mechanics: Spelling
Regular Words
Spell words phonetically, drawing on knowledge of phonemic awareness and spelling conventions.
Spell words correctly, using knowledge of meaningful word parts.
Spell words correctly by applying knowledge of spelling patterns and generalizations (e.g., word families, position-based spellings, syllable patterns, ending rules).
Irregular Words
Spell high-frequency irregular words correctly.
Sentence Structure
Phrases & Clauses
Construct independent and dependent clauses.
Construct phrases and clauses that use parallel structure.
Recognize and correct inappropriate fragments.
Recognize and correct run-on sentences, including comma splices.
Recognize and correct faulty or weak coordination and subordination of clauses.
Recognize and correct illogical placement of phrases and clauses, including misplaced and dangling modifiers.
Understand and explain the function of phrases in general and their function in specific sentences.
Understand and explain the function of independent and dependent clauses in general and their function in specific sentences.
Sentence Types
Produce simple declarative, negative, and exclamatory sentences.
Produce simple interrogative sentences, using question words appropriately.
Produce compound sentences, using appropriate coordination to link multiple independent clauses.
Produce complex sentences, using appropriate subordination to link one independent clause and one or more dependent clauses.
Produce compound-complex sentences using appropriate coordination and subordination to link two or more independent clauses and at least one dependent clause.
Variety
Use simple, compound, complex, and compound-complex sentences to express and connect ideas.
Use a variety of sentence structures, beginnings and lengths.
Use sentences that maintain/enhance coherence and cohesion within a paragraph or longer text.
Combine, expand, or reduce sentences to enhance clarity and style.
Text Level
Cohesion & Coherence
Deprecated (Revised / replaced by newer KSAO)

en-us:
V2.1 Replaced with H.A.LAL.LU.TXL.COH.3, H.A.LAL.LU.TXL.COH.4, & H.A.LAL.LU.TXL.COH.5
V2.0 Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of techniques for building cohesion.

competencyText.en-us: Deprecated (Revised / replaced by newer KSAO)

en-us:
V2.1 Replaced with H.A.LAL.LU.TXL.COH.6, H.A.LAL.LU.TXL.COH.7, & H.A.LAL.LU.TXL.COH.8
V2.0 Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of logical organization, including sequence of information, introductions and conclusions.

competencyText.en-us: Enhance cohesion through effective use of transition words and phrases.
Enhance cohesion through effective use of repetition, synonyms, and pronouns.
Enhance cohesion through sentence structure (e.g., parallelism, Known-New contract).
Enhance coherence through the logical ordering of phrases, sentences, and paragraphs.
Enhance coherence through the development of effective introductions and conclusions.
Enhance coherence through the development of effective transitions between paragraphs or sections of text.
Text Structures
Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of text structures, including organizational patterns and methods of development.
Understand how linguistic and structural elements commonly associated with different genre families or types of texts shape meaning.
Style
Use language that concisely communicates ideas, avoiding redundancy and unnecessary wording.
Determine appropriate language register (i.e., informal, formal, academic) based on rhetorical situation (purpose, audience, and context).
Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the impact of style and voice.
English as a Living Language
Varieties of English
Understand and appreciate the natural variations in language across different rhetorical situations, historical periods, and geographical regions in the English-speaking world.
Understand ways in which technology plays a role in language change (e.g., SMS, Twitter, email).
Understand that language use and formatting may vary across disciplines and professions and consult appropriate resources (e.g., MLA Handbook, Chicago Manual of Style).
Oral Language Foundations
Listening & Speaking
Speak audibly and clearly.
Pronounce words accurately.
Take turns appropriately when talking to others.
Follow and give simple instructions.
Participate actively in reciting or singing familiar texts.
Notice and ask questions when meaning is unclear.
Reword or restate ideas when asked.
Follow language use conventions appropriate to oral language.
Phonological Awareness
Identify and isolate syllables and phonemes in words.
Segment sounds (syllables and phonemes) in words.
Blend sounds (syllables and phonemes) in words.
Manipulate sounds in words by changing initial or ending phonemes.
Recognize and produce sound patterns such as rhyme and alliteration.
Written Language Foundations
Print Concepts
Demonstrate understanding of organizational features of print.
Use mouse or interactive features to navigate a digital text.
Show awareness of different types of text, including words used in the environment.
Phonics & Word Recognition
Decode regular words using letter-sound knowledge, syllable types, and phonics patterns.
Read and spell words with inflectional endings and high frequency prefixes.
Read and spell high frequency irregular words.
Fluency
Read words quickly and accurately.
Read text at appropriate rate.
Read aloud familiar text with appropriate pacing, intonation and expression.
Monitor comprehension and self-correct errors that impeded understanding.
Conventions & Mechanics
Use handwriting to produce text fluently and legibly.
Type to produce texts fluently and accurately.
Recognize the function of and use simple punctuation.
Behaviors
Using Reference Materials
Independently use resources (e.g., dictionaries, handbooks, and style guides) to answer questions about language, including pronunciation, meaning, and usage.
Disposition
Understand that words and images convey meaning and should make sense.
Demonstrate awareness of connections between oral, written, and visual language.
Understand that oral and written language often differ in conventional ways.
Develop awareness of, interest in, and metacognition about words and language.
Developing the knowledge and practices to comprehend and critique a wide range of written, spoken, and multimedia texts
Comprehension
Locate Information & Understand Literal Meaning
Scan for and locate key details in the text.
Recall key details from the text.
Deprecated (Revised / replaced by newer KSAO)

en-us:
V2.1 Replaced with H.A.LAL.CC.CPH.LIU.4 & H.A.LAL.CC.CPH..LIU.6
V2.0 Describe relationships between or among characters, events, objects, concepts, and/or linguistic or structural elements when the relationships are clearly stated in the text.

competencyText.en-us: Describe characters, individuals, and groups as presented in the text.
Recount or describe events or setting as presented in the text.
Describe relationships between or among characters, individuals, groups and events when the relationships are clearly stated in the text.
Integrate & Interpret
Identify the topic or gist of the text.
Determine the theme or central idea of the text.
Identify subordinate themes or ideas in the text.
Distinguish central ideas or themes from subordinate ideas or themes in the text.
Deprecated (Revised / replaced by newer KSAO)

en-us:
V2.1 Replaced with H.A.LAL.CC.CPH.INI.18 & H.A.LAL.CC.CPH.INI.20
V2.0 Describe relationships between or among characters, events, objects, concepts, and/or linguistic or structural elements when the relationships are implied in the text.

competencyText.en-us: Make elaborative (gap-filling) inferences to establish logical connections and draw reasonable generalizations from the text.
Explain how the text supports an inference.
Determine point of view in narrative texts.
Determine speaker in poetic texts.
Determine the perspective of the author and others in informational texts.
Interpret figurative language in the text.
Interpret information presented in graphical resources (e.g., charts, tables, graphs, diagrams, and illustrations).
Paraphrase particularly important, dense, or rich language.
Summarize information, ideas, or events from the text.
Apply information or ideas from a text to answer a question or solve a problem.
Apply information or ideas from a text to a new situation.
Identify text that supports an inference.
Describe relationships between or among characters, individuals, and groups when the relationships are implied in the text.
Apply knowledge of linguistic and structural elements to identify and describe key elements in the text.
Describe relationships between or among key elements (e.g., setting, plot, and characters) and concepts when the relationships are implied in the text.
Strategies & Metacognition
Use a variety of strategies (e.g., questioning, annotating, and previewing) to monitor and improve comprehension.
Establish and adjust purposes and goals for reading, listening to, and viewing the text.
Oral Reading Fluency
Pause appropriately, grouping words into meaningful phrases that indicate understanding of content.
Use punctuation cues.
Vary pace according to purpose and audience.
Use effective intonation, stress and expression that indicate comprehension.
Adjust pace, volume, and pronunciation to enhance meaning and expression.
Thinking Critically About Texts
Analyze
Analyze the main rhetorical purpose(s) of the text.
Analyze texts to determine the function of specific linguistic and/or structural elements.
Analyze texts to determine argument elements.
Analyze how part(s) of the text function within its overall structure.
Analyze how text relates to broad themes about the human experience.
Analyze how the author's perspective, including bias and stereotyping, influences the text.
Analyze how the author organizes the text.
Analyze how linguistic and/or structural elements contribute to the meaning or effectiveness of the text.
Deprecated (Revised / replaced by newer KSAO)

en-us:
V2.1 moved to SYN and revised (H.A.LAL.CC.TCT.SYN.1, H.A.LAL.CC.TCT.SYN.2)
V2.0 Reflect on what has been learned.

en-us:
V2.1 moved to SYN (H.A.LAL.CC.TCT.SYN.3)
V2.0 Reflect on what has been learned.

competencyText.en-us: Evaluate
Formulate opinions about texts.
Establish criteria for evaluating texts.
Evaluate texts aesthetically.
Evaluate techniques an author uses to accomplish his or her purpose with the text.
Evaluate the reasoning in arguments.
Evaluate evidence used to support arguments.
Evaluate how well the text has fulfilled a given purpose.
Evaluate the overall quality or effectiveness of the text.
Deprecated (Revised / replaced by newer KSAO)

en-us:
V2.1 moved to SYN (H.A.LAL.CC.TCT.SYN.5)
V2.0 Reflect on what has been learned.

competencyText.en-us: Synthesize
Compare and contrast how two or more texts address similar themes or topics.
Integrate information and ideas across texts.
Reflect on what has been learned.
Analyze the influence of author’s perspective and/or medium in different versions of the same text or event (e.g., print and film, different translators, modern interpretations).
Critique the text through different critical lenses; compare and evaluate different critical interpretations of a text.
Behaviors
Range
Read, listen to, and view a variety of print and nonprint text types.
Read, listen to, and view texts composed by authors from different time periods, cultures, genders, and ethnicities.
Read, listen to, and view texts for a variety of purposes.
Disposition
Demonstrate increasing confidence and independence in comprehension activities.
Demonstrate a positive attitude towards comprehension activities.
Use personal criteria to select texts (e.g., interest, knowledge of authors and genres, difficulty, recommendations of others).
Understand that critical comprehension enhances learning and reflection by encouraging deeper exploration of content and relationships.
Developing the knowledge and practices to create and compose a wide range of written, spoken, and multimedia texts for school and real life purposes
Composing for Different Purposes
Convey Experience & Emotions
Relate experience through point of view of character or other narrator or speaker.
Express feelings and thoughts.
Incorporate relevant actions, events, and details.
Develop characters through description, dialogue, and characters' thoughts and actions.
Articulate plot, including a beginning, middle, and end.
Establish cohesion through logical and effective transitions that emphasize the sequence of events and/or development of characters.
Use precise language, which might include sensory details, literary devices, and dialect to describe characters and setting, to enhance effect on reader.
Use different poetic forms that enhance meaning.
Inform & Explain
Establish a topic and the focus or main idea about that topic.
Incorporate information, providing an appropriate level of detail, relevant to the focus or main idea.
Use text format features (e.g., headings, labels, and bullets) to clarify meaning and enhance overall effect.
Develop understanding of the focus or main idea by elaborating on supporting information.
Use appropriate organizational strategies, which may include conventional text structures, to group related ideas and information.
Establish cohesion through logical and effective transitions that emphasize relationships between and among ideas and information.
Provide sense of closure by summarizing and/or reflecting on key points about the focus or main idea.
Use precise language, which might include discipline-specific vocabulary and technical terms, to clarify meaning.
Persuade & Argue
Analyze topic or issue that is focus of argument.
Establish a perspective on the topic or issue; focus perspective into a thesis claim or claims.
Incorporate counterclaims/arguments and responses, including qualifications to strengthen own thesis claim.
Develop chain of reasoning to support argument and to guide organization.
Provide evidence that supports arguments and counterarguments.
Use conventional text structures or organizational strategies to group related arguments, ideas, and information.
Establish cohesion through logical and effective transitions that emphasize the chain of reasoning.
Provide a sense of closure by reflecting on key points and emphasizing implications or calling reader to action.
Use precise language, which might include rhetorical devices and persuasive techniques, to enhance effect on the reader.
Skills & Strategies
Process Approach
Use a process approach to compose texts.
Manage the composition process to meet deadlines; show awareness that projects can require considerable time to complete (e.g., engage in planning and drafting ahead of deadlines).
Adjust composition processes and use them flexibly based on a given task (e.g., drafting for a long research paper vs. drafting for an on-demand writing test).
Idea Generation & Analysis
Identify the rhetorical situation, including purpose, audience, and context, that will guide development of the text.
Determine the focus or topic.
Generate ideas, gather information, and select relevant content.
Development
Explain and/or elaborate on a topic by providing support (e.g., facts, examples, and reasons).
Maintain focus on topic by including only relevant material.
Incorporate material that strengthens support and avoids redundancy.
Organization
Organize with a text structure appropriate to the rhetorical situation.
Use cohesive devices appropriate to the rhetorical situation.
Language Use & Conventions
Make language choices to establish and maintain an appropriate style and tone.
Review and revise language to enhance coherence, cohesion, and overall effectiveness.
Proofread and edit drafts to identify and correct issues with grammar, usage, mechanics and sentence structure.
Behaviors
Range
Compose texts for a variety of rhetorical situations.
Compose regularly, in a variety of contexts.
Compose a wide variety of written, spoken, and multimedia text types.
Compose texts across a variety of disciplines.
Study and analyze mentor texts.
Disposition
Sustain effort to complete complex composition tasks, seeking assistance as needed.
Demonstrate increasing confidence and independence in creating and composing.
Demonstrate a positive attitude towards composition.
Demonstrate audience awareness throughout all aspects of the composition process.
Explore concepts of genre, text type, and language use when reading published texts (i.e., apply Analysis skills from Critical Comprehension in order to learn about composition).
Understand that creating and composing enhances learning and reflection by encouraging deeper exploration of content and relationships.
Developing the knowledge and practices to communicate effectively in a variety of real time, dynamic oral and written contexts
Presentational
Presenter
Prepare for and practice delivery, including rehearsal with multimedia and other presentation aids.
Use notes, outline or other memory aids for reminders of main ideas, key concepts, and organization.
Strategically incorporate multimedia and other presentation aids to enhance understanding.
Use verbal and nonverbal cues to support organizational fluency and emphasize key points.
Engage audience using strategies (e.g., personal anecdotes, humor, and rhetorical questions) appropriate to the rhetorical situation.
Maintain focus on main ideas and key points.
Speak at a natural pace, with clear articulation and appropriate volume.
Demonstrate confidence, poise, and self-control, maintaining eye contact and appropriate pacing and vocalization.
Monitor audience response and adjust delivery when needed.
Anticipate audience response and address alternative or opposing perspectives when appropriate.
Respond to questions confidently, answering knowledgeably or offering hypothesized response if appropriate.
Audience
Demonstrate engagement with presenter.
Maintain focus on main ideas and key points.
Listen and view attentively for cues that signal transitions and key point.
Listen critically to informational and persuasive elements of presentations and flexibly move to other types of listening when appropriate.
Use a range of comprehension strategies appropriate for listening and viewing presentations.
Ask relevant questions for clarification, understanding, and elaboration at appropriate times.
Interpersonal
Conversation
Demonstrate attentiveness to the speaker.

Use language cues that reflect uncertainty when hypothesizing, speculating, imagining and exploring ideas rather than stating facts or firmly held opinions (e.g., “what if…,” “very likely…,” “I’m unsure whether…”).
Respond to questions with appropriate elaboration.
Emphasize understanding by paraphrasing what the speaker said.
Use a range of listening types appropriate for topic and context of conversation.
Initiate new topics.
Ask relevant questions for clarification, understanding, and elaboration at appropriate times.
Use listening comprehension strategies flexibly.
Respond constructively and disagree politely when appropriate.
Collaboration
Use group discussion practices (e.g., brainstorming, setting an agenda, and establishing group norms) appropriate to context and goal.
Participate in a variety of roles (e.g., critical listener, discussion leader, facilitator).
Attend to and elaborate on others' comments.
Offer relevant and productive comments, opinions, and questions confidently but without dominating.
Actively encourage peers to participate.
Be prepared and build trust with peers by completing tasks (including learning about topic/task) in a timely matter.
Use listening comprehension strategies flexibly.
Use a range of listening types appropriate for supporting group tasks and goals.
Behaviors
Disposition
Demonstrate a positive attitude and increasing confidence towards communicating with diverse audiences in different contexts.
Understand how use of language can enhance community with or emphasize distance from others.
Be aware of personal bias and avoid stereotyping others based on appearance and voice.
Demonstrate tolerance for different perspectives and ambiguity.
Demonstrate empathy and respect when communicating with others.
Understand that communicating with others enhances learning and reflection by exploring different perspectives, generating new ideas, and challenging assumptions.

Developing skills for engaging in a source-based research process, including development of critical questions and finding, accessing, evaluating, and applying information from a range of print and digital information sources.
Developing Questions & Planning the Task
Develop guiding, primary inquiry question(s) on a topic or in response to a text.
Develop supporting, elaborative questions around primary inquiry question(s).
Identify information needs around primary and supporting questions.
Develop a plan for answering questions and finding information; approach the problem strategically.
Searching & Gathering

Search for information from a range of information sources (including print and digital, primary and secondary sources) appropriate for accomplishing a given task; understand differences between types of sources.
Use a range of search techniques and technologies to find relevant information.
Identify and seek out librarians and others who can aid in the search process.
Use a search strategy appropriate to the domain or discipline (e.g., appropriate keywords/search terms for a given domain).
Refine search strategy to focus results and address gaps around information needs.
Gather sources, record citation information (“metadata”), and organize using a systemic approach and technology (e.g., reference list or citation management software) to facilitate source evaluation.
Sourcing & Evaluating

Attend to information about the source (e.g., author, date, publication) to evaluate source relevance, reliability, quality, bias, and credibility before engaging with source content (i.e., engage in “sourcing”).
Consider how the source is viewed by authorities in the field of inquiry.
Investigate the original context(s) in which the information was produced.
Read source content strategically to evaluate relevance, reliability, quality, bias, and credibility.
Determine author’s purpose, main idea(s), and perspective(s) in a source.
Identify, analyze, and evaluate arguments in sources, including author claims, counterclaims, and evidence.
Make connections between the content of a source and information about the source.
Corroborate information across sources and determine relationships between them; compare perspectives across sources; identify gaps and inconsistencies in information.
Create a map or model of sources, attending to points of agreement and disagreement among sources (e.g., draw a diagram of source relationships).
Integrate information within and across sources with prior knowledge into an organized, coherent understanding of the topic.

Evaluate quality of understanding of multiple sources according to task goals; identify gaps or inconsistencies and engage in further questioning, planning, searching, gathering, sourcing, and evaluating if necessary.
Applying
Understand the supporting, evidentiary role that source information plays in the learning process and its products (e.g., papers, presentations).

Use information from multiple sources to answers questions and construct knowledge on the topic: construct arguments, developing and critiquing claims and counterclaims using information drawn from multiple sources as evidence.

Use information from multiple sources to answers questions and construct knowledge on the topic: produce explanations, accurately using information drawn from multiple sources to provide detail and clarity.
Incorporate information/evidence from multiple sources into presentations.
Engage in informed discussions, using information from multiple sources to support and critique claims and to explain complex concepts.
Understand that information can be decontextualized and re-contextualized in ways that are strategic and deceptive.
Attribute information to sources accurately to avoid plagiarism; correctly use a citation style appropriate for the topic or discipline.
Understand that information has legal, political, economic, and ethical aspects; seek out and apply best practices for information use.
